sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Diabetic macular edema: 2 mg (0.05 mL) INTRAVITREALLY every 4 weeks for 5 injections, then 2 mg INTRAVITREALLY every 8 weeks; adequate anesthesia and a topical broad-spectrum microbicide should be given prior to the injection
  • Diabetic macular edema - Diabetic retinopathy: 2 mg (0.05 mL) INTRAVITREALLY every 4 weeks for 5 injections, then 2 mg INTRAVITREALLY every 8 weeks; give adequate anesthesia and a topical broad-spectrum microbicide prior to the injection
  • Exudative age-related macular degeneration: 2 mg (0.05 mL) INTRAVITREALLY every 4 weeks for 12 weeks, then once every 8 weeks; adequate anesthesia and a topical broad-spectrum microbicide should be given prior to the injection
  • Macular retinal edema - Thrombosis of retinal vein: 2 mg (0.05 mL) INTRAVITREALLY once every 4 weeks; adequate anesthesia and a topical broad-spectrum microbicide should be given prior to the injection

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• gender: dose adjustment not necessary
  • geriatric: dose adjustment not necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Diabetic macular edema
  • Diabetic macular edema - Diabetic retinopathy
  • Exudative age-related macular degeneration
  • Macular retinal edema - Thrombosis of retinal vein

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• active intraocular inflammation
  • hypersensitivity to aflibercept or any component of the product
  • ocular or periocular infections

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hematologic:
  • -- arterial thromboembolic events (eg, nonfatal stroke, nonfatal myocardial infarction, vascular death) have been reported
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- endophthalmitis and retinal detachments have been reported
  • -- acute increases in intraocular pressure have been reported within 60 minutes of administration; monitoring recommended
  • -- sustained increases in intraocular pressure have been reported after repeated administration; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Ophthalmic:Conjunctival hemorrhage (12% to 31%), Corneal erosion (2% to 7%), Pain in eye (4% to 13%), Vitreous floaters (1% to 8%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Myocardial infarction
  • Hematologic:Arterial thrombosis (Up to 6.4%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (Less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident
  • Ophthalmic:Cataract (Up to 19%), Endophthalmitis (Less than 1%), Raised intraocular pressure (2% to 9%), Retinal detachment (Less than 1%), Retinal tear (Less than 1%), Vitreous detachment (2% to 8%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Aflibercept binds to the angiogenic vascular endothelial growth factors (VEGF), VEGF-A, and placental growth factor (PIGF), to inhibit their binding to receptor tyrosine kinases and activation of VEGF-A, thereby inhibiting neovascularization and vascular permeability

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravitreal
  • intended for single-use only; discard any unused product
  • use a new vial if the contralateral eye requires treatment
  • use 5-micron filter needle to withdrawal aflibercept and switch to a 30-gauge, 0.5-inch needle for intravitreal injection

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• maintenance of visual acuity indicates efficacy
  • intraocular pressure elevation (eg, optic nerve head perfusion or tonometry); immediately after injection

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid driving or other activities requiring clear vision until visual function has returned to normal.
  • This drug may cause conjunctival hemorrhage, eye pain, cataracts, vitreous detachment, vitreous floaters, and increased intraocular pressure.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs or symptoms of endophthalmitis or retinal detachment (eye redness or pain, light sensitivity, or vision changes).
